article:
A 'group' in stratigraphy is a lithostratigraphic unit, a part of the geologic
record or rock column that consists of defined rock strata. Groups are generally
divided into individual formations. Groups may sometimes be divided into
"subgroups" and are themselves sometimes grouped into "supergroups".

Some well known groups of northwestern Europe have in the past also been used as
units for chronostratigraphy and geochronology. These are the Rotliegend,
Zechstein (both of Permian age), Buntsandstein, Muschelkalk, Keuper (Triassic in
age), Lias, Dogger and Malm (Jurassic in age) groups. Because of the confusion
this causes, the official geologic timescale of the ICS does not contain any of
these names any longer.
